journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Analysis of bimorph piezoelectric beam energy harvesters using Timoshenko and Euler–Bernoulli beam theory

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, University of Alabama in Huntsville, Huntsville, AL, USA

author-notes.corresp: Gang Wang, Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, University of Alabama in Huntsville, Huntsville, AL 35899, USA. Email: gang.wang@uah.edu

abstract.p: Single-degree-of-freedom lumped parameter model, conventional finite element method, and distributed parameter model have been developed to design, analyze, and predict the performance of piezoelectric energy harvesters with reasonable accuracy. In this article, a spectral finite element method for bimorph piezoelectric beam energy harvesters is developed based on the Timoshenko beam theory and the Euler–Bernoulli beam theory. Linear piezoelectric constitutive and linear elastic stress/strain models are assumed. Both beam theories are considered in order to examine the validation and applicability of each beam theory for a range of harvester sizes. Using spectral finite element method, a minimum number of elements is required because accurate shape functions are derived using the coupled electromechanical governing equations. Numerical simulations are conducted and validated using existing experimental data from the literature. In addition, parametric studies are carried out to predict the performance of a range of harvester sizes using each beam theory. It is concluded that the Euler–Bernoulli beam theory is sufficient enough to predict the performance of slender piezoelectric beams (slenderness ratio > 20, that is, length over thickness ratio > 20). In contrast, the Timoshenko beam theory, including the effects of shear deformation and rotary inertia, must be used for short piezoelectric beams (slenderness ratio < 5).

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Vibration-based piezoelectric energy harvesters (EHs) have been developed because of their high energy density. There have been numerous studies that have used a cantilever as the vibrating structure upon which the piezoelectric element is bonded. These piezoelectric beam energy harvester (PBEH) devices range from microelectromechanical system (MEMS) scale (Choi et al., 2006; Cook-Chennault et al., 2008; Devoe and Pisano, 1997; Du Toit et al., 2005) to macroscale size (Badel et al., 2005; Ottman et al., 2002; Sodano et al., 2004a, 2004b). State of the art of vibration-based PBEHs is discussed in a recent book by Erturk and Inman (2011). The PBEHs are very promising because they can power small electronic components and remote sensors in such diverse fields as mechanical, aerospace, civil, and medical applications. A comprehensive, accurate, and efficient mathematical model is essential to predict the dynamics of this electromechanical coupled piezoelectric beam system. As reviewed by Erturk and Inman (2011), three approaches are typically used for the analysis of such PBEHs: (a) lumped parameter model (LPM), (b) the Rayleigh–Ritz method, and (c) distributed parameter model.

The LPM was first used to predict the dynamics of the piezoelectric EH, which is a single-degree-of-freedom (SDOF) representation (Du Toit et al., 2005; Roundy and Wright, 2004). This method served as a simple analysis with which to determine maximum power extraction and to conduct preliminary sizing for a PBEH. However, the LPM is limited to a single vibration mode and does not provide sufficient physical insight into the coupled electromechanical system. Multiple uniform beam bending vibration mode shape functions based on the Euler–Bernoulli beam theory were used to spatially discretize the coupled electromechanical system using the Rayleigh–Ritz method (Sodano et al., 2004b). The Rayleigh–Ritz method enables an improved prediction of modal frequencies for a piezoelectric beam and captures the physical behavior of the coupled system. However, the solution is numerical, which can be computationally intensive if many modes are included.

Several efforts were pursued to yield an analytical representation based on the Euler–Bernoulli beam theory and linear piezoelectric constitutive equation (Chen et al., 2006; Lin et al., 2007; Lu et al., 2004). Key issues in modeling piezoelectric EHs were identified and discussed by Erturk and Inman (2008a), which include factors such as the lack of correct resonance response (damping neglected), ignoring modal expansions for a distributed parameter system, incorrect forcing due to base excitation, and others. Accordingly, an analytical distributed parameter method was developed by Erturk and Inman (2008b, 2008c) to investigate this electromechanical coupled system. In this method, the mode shape functions of a uniform Euler–Bernoulli beam are used to spatially discretize the coupled system and result in a set of uncoupled ordinary differential equations. Both air damping and strain-rate damping were included to capture the damped resonant dynamics of this coupled electromechanical system. Both structural and electrical responses were given analytically in compact expressions. In addition, this distributed parameter model was successfully validated by experimental data (Erturk and Inman, 2011). Although this distributed parameter model significantly improves the performance prediction of the PBEHs, one must include multiple beam mode shape functions in order to provide an accurate prediction. It is not an exact approach because the mode shape functions of the coupled electromechanical system are approximated by the mode shape functions from a uniform cantilevered beam under mechanical loading only, with neither the electrical effects nor the stiffness and mass of the piezoelectric materials.

Conventional finite element models (CFEMs) have also developed for piezoelectric beam system (Benjeddou et al., 1997; Kusculuoglu et al., 2004). However, the focus was on actuation using piezoelectric materials. Therefore, these finite element models (FEMs) cannot be directly applied to piezoelectric EHs unless the coupled electrical response and appropriate piezoelectric constitutive equations are included.

Spectral finite element method (SFEM), also called dynamic stiffness matrix method, is an alternative accurate structural analysis tool (Doyle, 1997; Gopalakrishnan et al., 2007; Lee, 2009; Leung, 1993; Wang and Wereley, 2002, 2004). The fundamental difference between the SFEM and the CFEM is that the displacement interpolation functions used in the SFEM are derived from exact solutions of the governing equations, whereas polynomial functions are used in the FEM. The governing equations are first transformed from the time domain to the frequency domain using a discrete Fourier transform (DFT). The spatial variation of the displacement field is determined semi-explicitly by solving the characteristic equation in the wave number space. This results in a complex shape function matrix representing the linear superposition of all the wave modes, and the solution is highly accurate. Also, the dynamic strain–displacement matrix and the dynamical force vector can be derived in a consistent manner. Key advantages of using the SFEM are as follows: (1) exact (or highly accurate) interpolation functions from the solutions of the governing differential equations are used, (2) only a single spectral finite element is needed to cover a large area of a structure, (3) substantially fewer elements are needed for SFEM than the CFEM for the improved level of accuracy, and (4) efficient DFT and inverse DFT algorithms allow accurate transient response predictions under any external forcing excitations. The SFEM has also been applied to piezoelectric beam analyses. Lee and Kim (2000) developed a spectral finite element for a two-layered piezoelectric beam with simplified kinematic assumption and the focus on the dynamic structural response although the piezoelectric constitutive equations were included. Park et al. (2010) developed a spectral finite element formulation for dynamic analysis of a coupled piezoelectric wafer and beam system, in which the Mindlin–Hermann and Timoshenko beam theories are employed for based beam, and the higher frequency wave responses were demonstrated in the structural health monitoring using piezoelectric wafer as a sensing element. Bonello and Rafique (2011) first extended the spectral finite element modeling to study the PBEH and derived a dynamic stiffness matrix under the Euler–Bernoulli beam theory. Both tip displacement and power frequency responses of a symmetric cantilevered piezoelectric beam were calculated and validated by the predictions using the distributed parameter model developed by Erturk and Inman (2008b, 2011). An impedance was introduced instead of a pure resistance to represent the electrical load. The derivation of the spectral finite element was not presented in an illustrative manner, and the governing equations were given in terms of moment and displacement.

In this study, a SFEM for a bimorph PBEH is developed, in which linear piezoelectric constitutive and either Euler–Bernoulli beam theory or Timoshenko beam theory are employed. A symmetric three-layered EH configuration is assumed to decouple the axial deformation. The purpose is to provide a clear and compact representation of the spectral finite element formulation. The top and bottom piezoelectric layers have identical geometry but can have different poling directions, that is, both series and parallel electrical arrangements are allowed (Erturk and Inman, 2011). First, both mechanical strain and electric displacement are selected as independent variables to represent the fully coupled electromechanical potential energy (Ikeda, 1990; Sirohi and Mahadik, 2011). Then, corresponding kinetic energy and external virtual work done by base excitation and voltage drop on a resistance load are defined. By applying Hamilton’s principle, the governing equations and associated boundary conditions are derived in terms of mechanical and electric displacements. Fundamental physics of this coupled electromechanical system is presented. By assuming harmonic excitation/response (i.e. transformation to the frequency domain), analytical solutions of the governing equations can be obtained. These solutions will be used to formulate the spectral finite element. Complex stiffness is introduced to equivalently represent the damping in the coupled system in order to capture resonance responses. Similar to the CFEM, after assembling elements and applying appropriate boundary conditions, both mechanical and electric responses can be determined accordingly. For a cantilevered bimorph piezoelectric beam, voltage, current, and power frequency response functions (FRFs) can be determined by solving a 2 × 2 linear algebraic equation. First, SFEM based on the Timoshenko beam theory is derived. Then, by neglecting shear deformation and rotary inertia, it yields a SFEM based on the Euler–Bernoulli beam theory. The purpose of having both SFEM approaches is to compare the predictions from two beam theories and provide a fundamental physical understanding of the coupled PBEH system. General guidelines are developed, so that each beam theory can be applied for the appropriate slenderness ratio, that is, length over thickness ratio, for bimorph PBEHs.

sec.title: SFEM
sec.p: Figure 1 shows a cantilevered bimorph piezoelectric beam. For simplification, two identical piezoelectric layers are assumed but different poling directions are allowed in order to demonstrate both series and parallel arrangements of these two piezoelectric layers. Other key assumptions are as follows:

list-item.p: Same transverse displacement across entire beam thickness
Perfect bonding between piezoelectric layer and base beam, that is, no slip.

caption.p: Schematic representation of a bimorph piezoelectric beam under base excitation.

sec.p: In the following sections “SFEM based on the Timoshenko beam theory” and “SFEM based on the Euler–Bernoulli beam theory,” the spectral finite element development for a bimorph piezoelectric beam will be demonstrated. First, the SFEM will be developed based on the Timoshenko beam theory. A brief discussion of SFEM based on the Euler–Bernoulli beam theory will also be presented.

sec.title: SFEM based on the Timoshenko beam theory
sec.p: As discussed by Doyle (1997), the wave numbers determined by the elementary Bernoulli–Euler beam theory are not valid after 3 kHz. The high-order Timoshenko beam theory must be used to account for shear deformation as well as the rotary inertia for higher frequency wave propagation. Typically, the vibration-based PBEHs are designed for low-frequency (<1 kHz) operation. Both beam theories should provide adequate accuracy for dynamic response predictions of a PBEH. Different sizes of PBEHs are built to accommodate different engineering applications. The slenderness ratio, that is, length over thickness ratio, also significantly affects beam responses (Timoshenko et al., 1974). This motivates the development of a SFEM of the piezoelectric beam based on the Timoshenko beam theory. A fundamental understanding of the slenderness effects on the piezoelectric beam responses is anticipated. Then, appropriate beam theory can be applied to PBEHs with different slenderness ratios.
Under a pure bending motion, the axial displacement is given by

The peak resonance response is critical in order to provide accurate voltage, current, and power predictions and is dictated by assumed or measured damping. Both viscous and air damping were simply introduced in the distributed parameter method (Erturk and Inman, 2011) because the beam mode shape functions were used to spatially discretize the governing equations. In the SFEM, a complex stiffness is introduced to equivalently represent the damping in the bimorph EH system, which results in a complex wave number of k. Finally, the transverse displacement

sec.p: Note that the spectral finite element is derived in the frequency domain. The total dynamic stiffness matrix is a function of frequency. The nodal force vector on the right-hand side of equation (47) is defined in the frequency domain. As aforementioned, for a general force input, the DFT is needed to determine the amplitude of each frequency component. Then, the nodal displacement vector can be solved accordingly in the frequency domain. Finally, the transient responses can be determined by conducting inverse DFT as discussed by Doyle (1997). For a bimorph piezoelectric cantilevered beam (as shown in Figure 1), one spectral finite element is needed. By applying boundary conditions at clamped end, one needs to simply solve the following linear algebra equation to determine both mechanical and electrical frequency responses

sec.title: Results
sec.p: In this section, the predictions of a bimorph piezoelectric beam (shown in Figure 1) using the SFEM (based on the Timoshenko beam theory) will be validated by the experimental results presented by Erturk and Inman (2011). Then, the slenderness effects on the piezoelectric EH performance predictions will be investigated. Fundamental resonance frequency, FRF predictions using both SFEMs based on the Euler–Bernoulli beam theory, and the Timoshenko beam theory will be discussed.

sec.title: Validation
sec.p: The same bimorph piezoelectric cantilever beam (as shown in Figure 1) investigated by Erturk and Inman (2011) was used to validate the SFEM predictions based on the Timoshenko beam theory. Table 1 shows the piezoelectric EH dimensions and material properties. Basically, it is a brass-reinforced bimorph manufactured by Piezo Systems Inc. The base beam is made of brass material, and the top and bottom piezoelectric layers are lead zirconate titanate (PZT)-5H and connected in series. This overhung length of this cantilevered beam is 24.53 mm. Other dimensions are listed in Table 1. The slenderness ratio is over 36. An electromagnetic shaker was used to excite the piezoelectric cantilever. Beam “tip” velocity 1.5 mm from tip end), harvested voltage, current, and power FRFs were measured under a variety of resistance loads and calibrated with respect to the acceleration level. Detailed experimental setup and testing procedure were described in Erturk and Inman (2011: ch. 4).

Only one spectral finite element is needed to capture the dynamics of this electromechanically coupled system. After applying the cantilevered boundary conditions, all calculations are conducted by solving a 2 × 2 linear algebraic equation in the frequency domain. In all simulations, a complex stiffness was used to represent the first modal damping, and the loss factor was set to
η = 0 . 0175
, which is equivalent to the viscous damping ratio of
ς = 0 . 00874
as assumed by Erturk and Inman (2011) under the first modal resonance condition.

Table 2 shows the predicted and measured resonance frequencies under short-circuit (R = 470 Ω) and open-circuit (R = 995 kΩ) conditions. Errors between the predicted and measured fundamental resonance frequencies under both short-circuit and open-circuit conditions are less than 1.2%. As discussed by Erturk and Inman (2011), the resonance frequency results predicted by the distributed parameter method are almost identical to the measured data. This slight discrepancy between the SFEM and the distributed parameter method is due to the value of beam flexural stiffness. Current flexural stiffness used in the SFEM is slightly higher than the short-circuit flexural stiffness assumed by Erturk and Inman (2011). In this case, the difference is less than 1.5%. Figure 3 shows the beam tip velocity and voltage FRF results under the short-circuit condition (i.e. R = 470 Ω). Experimental data were extracted and used to validate the SFEM predictions. Predictions correlate well with the experimental data. Figures 4 to 6 show the similar results under different resistance loading conditions, which varying from R = 1200 Ω to R = 995 kΩ (i.e. open circuit). It is shown that the SFEM predictions capture both mechanical and electrical responses. Figure 7 shows the power, current, voltage, and beam tip velocity FRFs under different resistance loads. From these results, the performance of this piezoelectric bimorph can be easily determined to identify the optimal operation condition (i.e. impedance matching) for energy harvesting application. It should be emphasized that only one element was used in the SFEM simulations compared to at least five mode shape functions applied in the distributed parameter model (Erturk and Inman, 2011).

caption.p: FRFs of beam tip velocity and harvested voltage, R = 470 Ω.
SFEM: spectral finite element method; FRFs: frequency response functions.
FRFs of beam tip velocity and harvested voltage, R = 1200 Ω.
SFEM: spectral finite element method; FRFs: frequency response functions.
FRFs of beam tip velocity and harvested voltage, R = 44.9 kΩ.
FRFs of beam tip velocity and harvested voltage, R = 995 kΩ.
SFEM: spectral finite element method; FRFs: frequency response functions.
FRFs predictions under different resistive loads: (a) tip velocity, (b) voltage, (c) power, and (d) current.

sec.p: In summary, the SFEM based on the Timoshenko beam theory was successfully validated using the experimental data in the literature. This model can be used to accurately predict the performance of the PBEHs.

sec.title: Comparisons
sec.p: Shear deformation and rotary inertia terms are included in the Timoshenko beam theory (Timoshenko et al., 1974). Both effects tend to lower the natural frequencies of beam bending vibration. Generally, it is not possible to obtain a closed-form solution for beams when shear deformation, flexural deformation, and rotary inertia are considered. However, for a pined-pinned beam, the reduction in the first modal frequency due to shear deformation and rotary inertia will be less than 5% if the slenderness ratio is greater than 5.7, in which a uniform rectangular beam is assumed (Blevins, 1979). In this section, the SFEMs based on both beam theories will be used to investigate the slenderness ratio effect on the performance predictions of the PBEHs.

Similar to the previous example, a bimorph piezoelectric cantilever is assumed as shown in Figure 1. The total length of the PBEH is 100 mm and the width is 20 mm. The same PZT-5H material constants are assumed in the top and bottom layers as listed in Table 1. However, each piezoelectric layer is 0.25 mm thick. The base beam is made of aluminum with Young’s modulus of 70 GPa and the density of 2700 kg/m3. The thickness of base beam varies from 1.5 to 19.5 mm to create different lengths over thickness ratios. Table 3 shows the fundamental resonance frequency predictions under both short-circuit and open-circuit conditions and different slenderness ratios. When the slenderness ratio is 50, the frequency results of the short-circuit and open-circuit conditions are exactly same. Both beam theories predict the same fundamental resonance frequency. However, as the slenderness ratio decreases, it is observed that the resonance frequency in the open circuit is slightly larger than that of the short circuit. Also, as expected, the Timoshenko beam theory predicts slightly lower resonance frequency compared to the case of the Euler–Bernoulli beam theory. The maximum error is within 4% when the slenderness ratio is reduced to 5. Figure 8 shows the FRF results of the tip displacement, voltage, power, and current using both theories, and the slenderness ratio is 50. The resistance is assumed to be 10 kΩ. Predictions are almost identical in this case. Figure 9 shows the similar results and the slenderness ratio is 5. Clearly, a small shift in the resonance frequency is observed as the slenderness ratio decreases. Because same amount of piezoelectric materials is assumed in all beam configurations. The harvest power shares same peak value. In order to quantitatively compare the predictions using both beam theories, a metric is defined to investigate the relative prediction errors between two beam theories. The relative area difference was calculated under each curve of beam tip displacement, voltage, power, and current plots predicted as shown in Figure 10. The maximum error is less than 2% when the slenderness ratio reaches 5. Clearly, the Euler–Bernoulli beam theory is sufficient enough to carry out the performance predictions of the piezoelectric beam EHs when the slenderness ratio is great than 20. The gain of using advanced Timoshenko beam theory is not quite obvious for slender beams as demonstrated in the textbook for the bending vibration of a uniform beam. However, one must apply the Timoshenko beam theory to analyze short piezoelectric beams because accurate prediction of the fundamental resonance frequency is crucial when determining optimal operational conditions for PBEHs.

caption.p: Fundamental resonance frequency predictions using both beam theories.
Comparison of frequency response functions predicted by both beam theories, R = 10 kΩ and slenderness ratio = 50: (a) tip displacement, (b) voltage, (c) power, and (d) current.
Comparison of frequency response functions predicted by both beam theories, R = 10 kΩ and slenderness ratio = 5: (a) tip displacement, (b) voltage, (c) power, and (d) current.
Relative prediction errors versus slenderness ratios, R = 10 kΩ: (a) tip displacement, (b) voltage, (c) power, and (d) current.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this article, the SFEMs for bimorph PBEHs were developed based on the Timoshenko beam and the Euler–Bernoulli beam theories. Linear piezoelectric material and linear elastic stress/strain relations were assumed. Key conclusions are summarized in the following.

list-item.p: Accurate approach. The governing equations of the electromechanical coupled piezoelectric beam system are derived and exactly solved in the frequency domain. These exact solutions are adopted for the shape functions used in the SFEM. This is why that the SFEM can accurately capture the underlying physics. Very few elements are required, which substantially reduces the computation cost. The number of element coincides with the impedance changes in the PBEHs.

Timoshenko and Euler–Bernoulli beam theory. SFEMs based on the Timoshenko and the Euler–Bernoulli beam theories were developed for a bimorph piezoelectric beam. Parametric studies were conducted to verify the applicability of each beam theory. Based on the simulation results, it was shown that the inclusion of shear deformation and rotary inertia has less effect on the performance predictions of slender piezoelectric beam EHs, in which the slenderness ratio is greater than 20, so that the Euler–Bernoulli beam theory is sufficient to carry out such an analysis. However, in order to accurately predict the fundamental resonance frequency of short piezoelectric beam harvesters (slenderness ratio < 5), the Timoshenko beam theory must be applied.

Adaptation. In this study, a symmetric configuration was assumed, so that the bending and axial deformation is decoupled. The purpose is to provide a clear and compact formulation of the SFEM for the piezoelectric beam analysis. Definitely, one can include both axial and torsion motions to develop a general case of a piezoelectric beam under coupled deformation. Typically, a tip mass is introduced to tune the resonance frequency to accommodate different excitation conditions. This term can be simply included in the kinetic energy expression. Eventually, it will appear in the boundary conditions, and an additional term will be introduced to the dynamic stiffness matrix.

sec.p: In summary, the SFEM has been extended to piezoelectric beam EH analysis. Experimental data were used to validate the SFEM predictions, and excellent correlations were obtained. Therefore, these newly developed spectral finite element models can be used to conduct design, analysis, and optimization of the piezoelectric beam EHs.
